CW4’s account that Blair ‘yelled’ and said he and investor relations ‘made up’ better projections after the Q1 2022 call is not pleaded with sufficient detail to support knowledge of falsity of any specific public statement: the Complaint does not identify the particular projections discussed, the numbers proposed by subsidiaries, the numbers ‘made up,’ how they mapped to the specific public guidance later issued, or that the public statements were false as opposed to management’s selection among uncertain forecast inputs. Even crediting CW4, the allegation supports at most aggressive optimism or internal disagreement about forecasting, not a particularized showing that Blair (or McGrew/Ligner) knew specific public statements were false when made.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not adequately pleaded. Considering the allegations holistically and weighing competing inferences, the more compelling inference is nonfraudulent: Danaher faced an unusually volatile transition from pandemic-driven demand to endemic/post-pandemic normalization, with long lead times, backlog conversion, changing customer order cadence, and evolving inventory behavior. The Complaint itself describes plausible business reasons for guidance changes (e.g., customers repurposing inventory, funding tightening, China slowdown emerging during Q2 2023). Repeated downward revisions, standing alone, do not create scienter; they are at least as consistent with forecasting error, changing macro/industry conditions, and management learning more over time.

The insider-sales allegations (Blair and McGrew) and PSU/TSR incentives do not establish a strong inference of scienter. The Complaint does not plead facts showing the trades were unusual in timing or amount relative to prior trading history, were inconsistent with preexisting plans, or were made while Defendants possessed specific, contradictory nonpublic facts. Assertions that a 10b5-1 plan ‘may’ have been adopted during the class period are speculative. Motive and opportunity allegations cannot substitute for particularized contemporaneous knowledge.

Finally, allegations framed as Item 303 ‘known trends’ omissions do not independently establish scienter absent particularized facts that Defendants actually knew of a specific, then-existing trend/uncertainty that made their statements misleading at the time. The Complaint pleads the trend (destocking/funding constraints) largely through later admissions and subsequent results, which risks impermissible fraud-by-hindsight.

Because Plaintiffs fail to plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference of scienter for any Defendant as to any actionable misstatement/omission, Count I is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Blair and McGrew)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation of the Exchange Act. Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim (Count I) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter with particularity under the PSLRA, the Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter with particularity and to allege facts giving rise to a strong inference of intent to deceive (or severe recklessness) as to any defendant at the time of the challenged statements. The complaint largely pleads a conflicted process and alleged disclosure deficiencies, but it does not plead particularized contemporaneous facts showing that any identified defendant actually knew specific statements were false when made, as opposed to advocating an arguably self-interested view of the deal and process. Count II (Section 14(a)/Rule 14a-9) is sustained at the pleading stage because it is expressly pleaded as negligence and alleges concrete omissions/misstatements about conflicts and banker compensation that could be material to a shareholder vote. Count III (Section 20(a)) is dismissed to the extent it is predicated on the dismissed Section 10(b) claim, but sustained to the extent it is predicated on the surviving Section 14(a) claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(a)-(c) (scheme liability) against all defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint identifies alleged misstatements/omissions in the press release and proxy (e.g., “independent and disinterested,” “robust process,” “best value reasonably obtainable,” and alleged omissions regarding conflicts, banker fees, and bidder interactions). But the scienter allegations are largely generalized: defendants “knew or recklessly disregarded” because the transaction was important, they held senior positions, and they had access to information. Those are classic ‘must have known’/corporate-knowledge allegations and do not supply particularized facts showing that any specific defendant (e.g., Adolf, Kodialam, McGranahan, Shanahan, Chang, LeMieux, Neuhoff, Morganroth, Feliciani, Carey, Muhtadie) actually knew that a specific challenged statement was false at the time it was made. The complaint does not plead, for example, who drafted particular statements, who reviewed them, what exact contrary facts were presented to each speaker at the time, or contemporaneous communications demonstrating awareness that the disclosures were misleading.

The complaint’s strongest factual material concerns (i) committee minutes about discussions of bidder interest and process, (ii) the existence of TRA-related incentives, (iii) the timing/amount of committee and Jefferies fee increases, and (iv) Goldman’s concurrent KSFB/NKSFB engagement. Even accepting those as true, they do not, without more, establish that defendants subjectively understood that describing the committee as ‘independent’ or the process as ‘robust’ was false in the securities-fraud sense at the time of publication, rather than an arguable characterization, a materiality dispute, or (at most) negligence about what needed to be disclosed.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: No strong inference. The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that defendants pursued and defended a preferred transaction structure (private equity buyer, rollover, certainty of closing) and made disclosure judgments that plaintiffs contend were incomplete. That is an innocent/non-fraudulent explanation at least as plausible as an intent to deceive the market. The complaint’s ‘additional allegations of scienter’ rely heavily on motive/opportunity (TRAs, rollover, retention, fees) and the importance of the transaction, but motive and importance do not substitute for particularized contemporaneous facts of knowing falsity. The allegations also resemble fraud-by-hindsight: plaintiffs infer fraudulent intent from the later-revealed details and from the assertedly ‘better’ $55 indication, without pleading particularized facts that defendants knew their public statements were false when made.

Accordingly, Count I is dismissed under the PSLRA for failure to plead scienter with particularity and failure to allege facts giving rise to a strong inference of scienter.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 14(a) and Rule 14a-9 against Focus, Special Committee Defendants, Board Defendants, and Officer Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not an element as pleaded here; plaintiffs expressly disclaim fraud and plead negligence. The complaint alleges specific proxy statement representations and omissions concerning (among other things) Special Committee independence/disinterestedness, Special Committee compensation increases approved immediately before the merger approval, Jefferies’ discretionary fee increase immediately before its fairness opinion, and Goldman’s conflicts and alleged effects on bidder outreach. These are concrete factual allegations tied to identified disclosures and could be material to a reasonable shareholder’s voting decision. At the motion-to-dismiss stage, those allegations plausibly state a Section 14(a)/Rule 14a-9 claim (subject to later proof of materiality, causation/essential link, and any loss causation limitations).

claim_rulings.claim: Count III — Section 20(a) control person liability against Special Committee Defendants, Board Defendants, and Officer Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed, Count III is dismissed to the extent it is predicated on an underlying Section 10(b) violation. However, Count II (Section 14(a)/Rule 14a-9) survives, and Section 20(a) may be predicated on an underlying Exchange Act violation other than Section 10(b). Accordingly, Count III is sustained only insofar as it is based on the surviving Section 14(a) claim and otherwise dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Court focuses on whether the complaint pleads with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that each defendant (especially the Individual Defendants) acted with intent to deceive or with deliberate recklessness at the time of the challenged statements. Although the complaint pleads extensive facts suggesting Walmart had serious CSA compliance problems and that DOJ/DEA activity existed, it largely fails to plead particularized facts showing that McMillon or Biggs actually knew specific SEC-filing statements were false when made (or were deliberately reckless as to their falsity). Much of the scienter theory rests on generalized “core operations,” committee membership, and assertions that it is “inconceivable” executives were unaware—precisely the type of speculation and corporate-knowledge pleading the PSLRA does not permit. The strongest scienter allegations concern McMillon’s consultation on the July 2018 DOJ presentation and the Company’s knowledge that indictment was contemplated; however, the complaint still does not tie those facts to particular challenged statements with the required specificity, nor does it plead facts making fraudulent intent at least as compelling as non-fraudulent explanations (e.g., disputed disclosure judgments about investigations, materiality, and confidentiality of investigative processes). Accordingly, Count I is dismissed for failure to plead a strong inference of scienter, and Count II is dismissed as derivative.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Walmart, McMillon, Biggs)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: The complaint identifies categories of alleged misstatements/omissions (non-disclosure of investigations/MOA; ASC 450/Item 103/contingencies language; risk-factor boilerplate; opioid ‘stewardship’ statements; SOX certifications). But it does not plead, with the required particularity, facts showing that McMillon or Biggs actually knew that the specific statements in the cited 10-Ks/10-Qs/press release were false at the time of issuance. The pleading relies heavily on (a) their corporate roles, (b) membership on the Ethics, Compliance and Risk Committee, (c) assertions they ‘would have received’ compliance documents, and (d) conclusions that it is ‘inconceivable’ they were unaware. Those are generalized corporate-knowledge allegations, not particularized facts of contemporaneous awareness of falsity.

The complaint cites internal documents (e.g., 2013 risk assessment, 2014 portfolio scoring worksheet, 2015 proposal) and DOJ/MDL materials showing Walmart’s compliance issues and government scrutiny. But it does not plead who provided those documents to McMillon or Biggs, when they reviewed them, what they read, and how that knowledge rendered particular SEC disclosures knowingly false as opposed to arguably incomplete or framed at a higher level of generality. Similarly, allegations that Walmart produced documents and met with DOJ prosecutors do not, without more, establish that the Individual Defendants knew the precise disclosure language in SEC filings was false (as opposed to believing disclosure obligations were satisfied by generalized references to subpoenas/investigations or by existing litigation disclosures).

The July 2018 ‘reverse proffer’/planned indictment allegations and the assertion that McMillon was consulted on the DOJ presentation are the most concrete. Even so, the complaint does not connect those facts to a particular challenged statement with the required specificity (e.g., identifying a specific filing/statement after July 2018 and alleging facts showing McMillon/Biggs knew that statement’s wording was false, not merely that an investigation existed). The pleading also does not allege specific internal communications showing the Individual Defendants directed concealment of the investigations from investors or discussed the falsity of the disclosure language.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: Considering the allegations holistically, the inference that defendants acted with fraudulent intent is not as compelling as nonculpable inferences. A plausible innocent (or at least non-fraudulent) inference is that defendants made disclosure judgments about (i) whether investigative activity rose to the level requiring Item 103 disclosure as a ‘material legal proceeding’ or ‘contemplated’ proceeding, (ii) whether and when ASC 450 required specific disclosure versus generalized disclosure, and (iii) how to describe ongoing government inquiries without prejudicing the Company’s position. The complaint’s reliance on later DOJ allegations, later MDL findings/abatement orders, and post-class-period outcomes risks impermissible ‘fraud by hindsight’—using later-developed facts to infer earlier intent.

Motive allegations (profit, driving sales, avoiding compliance costs) are generic and apply to many companies; they do not substitute for particularized facts of intent to deceive investors. The cited discovery disputes/sanctions in other litigation and assertions of non-cooperation with prosecutors may suggest adversarial litigation conduct, but they do not, without particularized linkage to the challenged investor statements at the time made, create a strong inference of securities-fraud scienter.

Because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that each defendant acted with intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness as to the truth of the challenged statements when made, Count I is dismissed under the PSLRA.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (against McMillon, Biggs)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation of the Exchange Act. Because the Court dismisses Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) for failure to plead scienter adequately under the PSLRA, Count II is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, Count II (Exchange Act §10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts showing any identified defendant’s contemporaneous knowledge of falsity (or severe recklessness) when the challenged statements were made. The allegations rely heavily on “upon information and belief,” “knew or should have known,” later nonperformance (withdrawal freeze), and generalized assertions of a fraudulent scheme—insufficient to create a strong inference of scienter that is at least as compelling as innocent explanations (e.g., liquidity/provider failure, operational collapse, inability to process withdrawals). Non-Exchange Act claims are not subject to the PSLRA scienter requirement and are evaluated only at a high level on plausibility; on the face of this pleading, Counts I and III–XI are plausibly alleged and are sustained for present purposes (without prejudice to later, more targeted challenges). No §20(a) claim is pleaded in this complaint; if it were, it would be dismissed as derivative of the dismissed §10(b) claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Securities Act §§ 5 and 12(a)(1) (unregistered offer/sale) against CFT and FxWinning
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not an element of a §12(a)(1) claim. The complaint pleads interstate solicitation and sale of an alleged “investment contract” (Howey) and alleges no registration statement. At the pleading stage, those allegations are sufficient to proceed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Exchange Act §10(b) and Rule 10b-5 against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, and Brito Cutie
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: The complaint does not plead specific, contemporaneous facts showing that any named defendant actually knew the challenged statements were false when made. The pleading repeatedly alleges defendants “knew (or should have known),” that statements were “easily verifiable,” and that “upon information and belief” no software/trading/insurance/audit existed, but it does not identify concrete internal reports, communications, admissions, dates, or witnesses tying any specific defendant to knowledge of falsity at the time of the Telegram/website/Zoom statements. The allegation that “Merino’s assistant has confirmed that Merino knew FxWinning was fraudulent” is conclusory as pleaded: it does not identify the assistant, when the statement was made, what exactly was said, or how it establishes Merino’s (or others’) knowledge at the time of the relevant misrepresentations.

2) Strong inference of scienter: The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that defendants later became unable (or unwilling) to process withdrawals due to business failure, liquidity-provider issues, regulatory/KYC disruptions, or operational collapse, and then gave shifting or overly optimistic explanations. The complaint’s core scienter theory largely rests on nonperformance (withdrawals stopped), later events (closure notice), and generalized allegations that the enterprise was a “scheme” from inception. That is classic fraud-by-hindsight and speculation about what defendants “must have known.” Even if the allegations support wrongdoing, they do not, as pleaded, create a strong inference of intentional deception (or severe recklessness) that is at least as compelling as these innocent or non-fraudulent explanations. Accordingly, Count II is dismissed under the PSLRA.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Commodity Exchange Act §§ 6b, 6e, 6o, and 25 against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, and Brito Cutie
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint alleges solicitation of pooled retail forex trading, misrepresentations about trading/returns/withdrawals, and misappropriation. Those allegations are sufficient at this stage to state a plausible CEA claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IV – Florida Securities and Investor Protection Act §§ 517.301 and 517.211 against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, and Brito Cutie
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint pleads offers/sales of an alleged security in Florida-connected conduct and materially misleading statements/omissions. At the pleading stage, the allegations are sufficient to proceed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count V – Breach of Contract against FxWinning
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint pleads the existence of FxWinning terms and conditions (including an asserted withdrawal right), breach by refusing withdrawals, and damages. Plausibly stated.

claim_rulings.claim: Count VI – Breach of Fiduciary Duty against all Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint plausibly alleges entrustment/control over funds and wrongful withholding/misappropriation. Whether a fiduciary relationship exists as a matter of law may be contested later, but dismissal is not warranted on this pleading alone.

claim_rulings.claim: Count VII – Fraud in the Inducement against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, and Brito Cutie
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint identifies categories of alleged misrepresentations (returns, security/segregation, ability to withdraw, audit/insurance/regulation) and reliance leading to deposits. Adequacy under Rule 9(b) is not fully analyzed here, but on the face of the allegations the claim is plausibly pleaded.

claim_rulings.claim: Count VIII – Negligent Misrepresentation against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, and Brito Cutie
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint alleges false information supplied for guidance of others, failure to use reasonable care, reliance, and damages. Plausibly stated.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IX – Conversion against all Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint alleges specific funds deposited, ownership, demand for withdrawal, and refusal/withholding. Plausibly stated.

claim_rulings.claim: Count X – Unjust Enrichment against all Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint alleges conferral of a benefit (deposits/fees/commissions), knowledge/acceptance, and inequity in retention given non-return of funds. Plausibly stated (subject to later arguments about adequacy where an express contract governs).

claim_rulings.claim: Count XI – Civil Conspiracy against all Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim. The complaint alleges a common purpose to defraud, coordinated acts (joint marketing/events, representations, withholding), and resulting damages. Plausibly stated at this stage.

response.summary: The complaint pleads only Securities Act claims under Sections 11 and 15 arising from alleged material misstatements/omissions in the IPO Registration Statement about GoHealth’s planned 2020 “investment year,” carrier expansion, commission/LTV compression, increased marketing spend, and churn/persistency impacts (including SNP mix). No Exchange Act Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claims are asserted, so PSLRA scienter analysis is not applicable and no Section 20(a) derivative claims are present. Applying Rule 12(b)(6) standards for Sections 11 and 15 (which do not require scienter), the Section 11 claim is adequately pleaded as to materially misleading omissions and Item 303/105 theories at the pleading stage; the Section 15 claim is adequately pleaded as derivative control-person liability based on alleged control and participation.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 11 of the Securities Act (15 U.S.C. § 77k) against GoHealth, the Individual Defendants, and the Underwriter Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not applicable. Section 11 is a strict-liability/negligence-based claim and does not require pleading that any defendant knew statements were false when made or that facts create a strong inference of scienter. The complaint alleges with sufficient specificity that the Registration Statement omitted material information about then-known operational/strategic trends (planned rapid carrier expansion, expected lower commissions/LTV, increased SNP/non-commission revenue mix, increased marketing spend, and churn/persistency impacts) and that certain optimistic statements about scalability/unit economics and risk factors were misleading in light of those omissions. Those allegations are sufficient at the motion-to-dismiss stage to plead a materially misleading registration statement and a plausible basis for liability under Section 11, including under Item 303/105 omission theories.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 15 of the Securities Act (15 U.S.C. § 77o) against GoHealth, the Individual Defendants, NVX Holdings, and Centerbridge
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not applicable. Section 15 is derivative of an underlying Securities Act violation and does not require PSLRA scienter pleading. Because the Section 11 claim is adequately pleaded, the complaint plausibly alleges control-person liability by pleading (i) an underlying Section 11 violation and (ii) control, including allegations that the Individual Defendants signed the Registration Statement and held senior leadership roles, and that NVX Holdings/Centerbridge possessed majority voting power and exercised control as a ‘controlled company’ structure described in the Registration Statement. Those allegations suffice to proceed at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 10(b) / Rule 10b-5 (Exchange Act)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: No such claim is pleaded in the complaint. Accordingly, there are no particularized allegations of contemporaneous knowledge of falsity and no basis to assess a strong inference of scienter under the PSLRA.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 20(a) control person liability (Exchange Act)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: No Section 20(a) claim is pleaded. In any event, Section 20(a) is derivative of an underlying Exchange Act violation; with no pleaded (and no viable) Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim, any Section 20(a) theory would be dismissed.

response.summary: The complaint, as pleaded, does not assert any Section 10(b) / Rule 10b-5 misrepresentation-based securities fraud claim, and therefore the PSLRA scienter analysis is not triggered for any pleaded cause of action. The operative federal securities claims are rescission/voiding claims under Exchange Act § 29(b) predicated on alleged violations of Exchange Act § 15(a) (unregistered dealer activity), plus a § 20(a) control-person claim derivative of the alleged § 15(a)/§ 29(b) violations. Those claims do not require pleading scienter under the PSLRA. On the face of the complaint, plaintiff pleads substantial facts about the structure and performance of the convertible notes, defendants’ alleged repeated course of similar transactions, and defendants’ non-registration status, which are sufficient at the pleading stage to sustain the § 29(b) claims. The § 20(a) claim is sustained to the extent it is predicated on sustained underlying Exchange Act violations. The RICO and equitable state-law claims are not subject to PSLRA scienter standards; the Court rules on them under ordinary plausibility standards as reflected below.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Exchange Act § 29(b) rescission/voiding based on alleged violation of Exchange Act § 15(a) (unregistered dealer) in making the DarkPulse Transactions
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. The complaint pleads with specificity that FirstFire is not registered as a dealer; that it regularly purchases convertible notes, converts into issuer shares at discounts, and sells into the public market; and that it did so here through identified Notes and identified conversions. Those factual allegations plausibly support that FirstFire was acting as a 'dealer' and used interstate instrumentalities in connection with the contracts’ formation, sufficient at the motion-to-dismiss stage for a § 29(b) claim predicated on § 15(a).

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Exchange Act § 29(b) rescission/voiding based on alleged violation of Exchange Act § 15(a) (unregistered dealer) in performance of the Agreements (conversions and sales)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. The complaint pleads detailed performance transactions (dates, debt amounts converted, and share quantities), and alleges immediate resale/dumping and use of interstate commerce. These allegations plausibly plead performance involving a continuing § 15(a) violation, supporting a § 29(b) performance-based rescission theory at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Exchange Act § 20(a) control person liability against Fireman (predicated on Counts I and II)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a plausible underlying Exchange Act violation plus control. Because Counts I and II are sustained at the pleading stage, and the complaint alleges Fireman’s role as managing member/ultimate decision-maker who negotiated and signed the Notes and directed conversions and sales, the control-person claim is plausibly pleaded.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IV – RICO, 18 U.S.C. § 1962(c) (conducting enterprise affairs through collection of unlawful debt)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. The complaint pleads the alleged enterprise, Fireman’s direction/control, the allegedly usurious terms (including commitment shares and conversion discounts), and collection via issuance of shares upon conversion. At the pleading stage, these allegations plausibly state a RICO unlawful-debt theory.

claim_rulings.claim: Count V – Unjust enrichment
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. Plaintiff pleads a concrete benefit conferred (shares/value obtained via conversions and commitment shares) and alleges inequity in retention given the alleged statutory violations and usury theory. Sufficient at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Count VI – Constructive trust
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter pleading is not required. The complaint identifies specific property (DarkPulse shares/value) allegedly wrongfully obtained and retained, and pleads circumstances alleged to make retention inequitable. Sufficient at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 10(b) / Rule 10b-5 (if asserted)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: No Section 10(b) / Rule 10b-5 cause of action is actually pleaded, and the complaint does not identify any actionable misstatement/omission to purchasers/sellers, reliance, loss causation, or damages under that theory. Even if the Court construed the narrative as attempting to allege fraud, the allegations do not plead with particularity that any defendant made a specific false statement with contemporaneous knowledge of falsity; instead they primarily allege an allegedly predatory business model and unfavorable contract terms, which is not a substitute for PSLRA-particularized scienter. Innocent explanations (arms-length contractual enforcement; dispute over default/price mechanics) are at least as plausible as fraudulent intent on the present pleading.

claim_rulings.claim: Exchange Act § 20(a) control person liability (to the extent predicated on any dismissed Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 theory)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Derivative of the underlying violation. Because any Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is not pleaded and, in any event, would be dismissed for failure to plead PSLRA scienter with particularity, any § 20(a) theory premised on a 10b-5 violation is dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Complaint pleads with particularity (i) contemporaneous regulator rejection letters and meeting feedback addressed to, received by, and discussed among specific individual defendants (especially Sloan and Duke), (ii) internal board emails acknowledging the rejections and their materiality to investors, and (iii) specific allegations of deliberate “toning down” of SEC disclosures to avoid revealing the true status. These allegations support a strong inference that certain defendants—most clearly Sloan and Duke—knew key public statements about being in “execution/implementation” and having “plans in place” were false when made. As to other individuals (notably Shrewsberry and Parker), the Complaint relies more heavily on role-based access and generalized assertions of what senior executives ‘must have known,’ with fewer particularized facts tying them to receipt of specific rejection communications at the time of their statements. Because Count I is pleaded as a single Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim against Wells Fargo and multiple individuals, and the Complaint alleges corporate scienter and particularized knowledge by at least some senior officers/directors who made or approved the challenged statements, Count I is sustained as to Wells Fargo, Sloan, and Duke, but dismissed as to Shrewsberry and Parker for failure to plead scienter with the required particularity. Count II (Section 20(a)) is sustained only to the extent it is predicated on a surviving primary violation and adequately pleaded control as to the remaining primary violators; it is dismissed as to defendants for whom the primary claim is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (Against Wells Fargo, Sloan, Parker, Duke, Shrewsberry)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) PARTICULARIZED KNOWLEDGE OF FALSITY: The Complaint pleads specific, contemporaneous documents and communications showing actual knowledge (not hindsight). It alleges that the Federal Reserve sent a May 7, 2018 rejection letter addressed to Sloan and Duke stating the Stage 1 plan was “materially incomplete” and “insufficient,” and a March 11, 2019 rejection letter again addressed to Sloan and Duke citing “pervasive inaccuracies” and “illogical timeframes,” and warning of “additional actions” upon a third failure. It further pleads OCC rejection letters (July 24, 2018; Nov. 21, 2018) and subsequent OCC communications (Feb. 15, 2019 email; March 4, 2019 report) describing “poor-quality action plans” and “unacceptable” response. These are pleaded as received by, discussed with, or directed to specific defendants (especially Sloan and Duke). The Complaint also pleads internal board emails (e.g., Craver’s “we totally biffed it”) and Duke’s meeting-summary email reporting the OCC said “all their input had been ignored,” supporting contemporaneous awareness.

It also pleads an affirmative concealment episode: Sloan and Duke allegedly agreed to “tone down” proxy disclosures and remove “substantial amount of work remaining,” with Sloan expressing concern that truthful disclosure would signal the bank was “not close to lifting of the asset cap.” This is a particularized allegation of intent to avoid disclosure.

2) STRONG INFERENCE VS INNOCENT EXPLANATIONS: As to Sloan and Duke, the inference of scienter is strong and at least as compelling as nonculpable explanations. The alleged facts are not merely that compliance was difficult or that timelines slipped; rather, they allege that regulators repeatedly rejected plans as noncompliant while Sloan/Duke publicly represented the bank had “plans in place,” was “executing,” and was “in the midst of implementing,” and they allegedly edited disclosures to avoid admitting “substantial” remaining work. The alleged private apology by Sloan to the Federal Reserve for “mischaracterizations” further supports consciousness of wrongdoing.

However, as to Shrewsberry and Parker, the Complaint’s scienter allegations are materially weaker. Although it alleges they spoke publicly and were senior executives, it pleads fewer particularized facts showing they personally received or reviewed the specific rejection letters or were present at the key meetings at the relevant times. Much of the pleading as to them relies on generalized ‘tone at the top’ and access-to-information assertions. Innocent explanations (e.g., reliance on compliance teams, imprecise phrasing about ‘execution’ as internal work rather than regulator-approved implementation) are comparatively more plausible absent particularized allegations tying them to the rejection communications contemporaneously.

Accordingly, Count I is sustained as to Wells Fargo (corporate scienter adequately pleaded through alleged knowledge and conduct of senior leadership who made/approved statements) and as to Sloan and Duke; but the scienter requirement is not adequately pleaded as to Shrewsberry and Parker, and the claim is dismissed as to them.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (as to Defendant Sloan)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) PARTICULARIZED KNOWLEDGE: Sloan is specifically alleged to have received/been addressed on the FRB May 7, 2018 and March 11, 2019 rejection letters; to have requested extensions acknowledging inability to submit an acceptable plan; to have altered SEC proxy disclosures to remove “substantial” remaining work; to have testified to Congress that the bank was “in compliance” and “executing” while allegedly knowing regulators had rejected the plans; and to have privately apologized to the Federal Reserve for mischaracterizations.

2) STRONG INFERENCE: These allegations support a strong inference of intent or at least deliberate recklessness, stronger than innocent explanations. The alleged conduct is not merely optimistic projections; it involves contemporaneous regulator rejections and alleged deliberate disclosure editing to avoid investor understanding of noncompliance.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (as to Defendant Duke)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) PARTICULARIZED KNOWLEDGE: Duke is specifically alleged to have received/been addressed on the FRB rejection letters; to have attended an April 3, 2018 meeting with the Federal Reserve about deficiencies; to have served as regulator point of contact; to have summarized the August 11, 2018 OCC meeting in an email stating OCC said input was ignored; and to have agreed with Sloan to “tone down” proxy disclosures. These are particularized facts of contemporaneous knowledge.

2) STRONG INFERENCE: Given repeated regulator rejections and Duke’s alleged agreement to reduce disclosure to avoid signaling the asset cap would not be lifted soon, the inference of scienter is cogent and compelling.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (as to Defendant Shrewsberry)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) PARTICULARIZED KNOWLEDGE: The Complaint alleges Shrewsberry made several challenged statements (e.g., investors know everything material; ‘last mile’; timing of asset cap), but it does not plead with comparable particularity that Shrewsberry personally received or reviewed the key FRB/OCC rejection letters at the time, or identify specific communications to him showing actual knowledge of falsity when he spoke. The pleading largely relies on his CFO role and Operating Committee membership.

2) STRONG INFERENCE: Without particularized contemporaneous facts tying Shrewsberry to the rejection letters/meetings, a nonculpable inference—miscommunication, reliance on subordinates, or imprecise characterization of internal work as ‘execution’—is at least as plausible as fraudulent intent. PSLRA scienter is therefore not adequately pleaded as to Shrewsberry.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (as to Defendant Parker)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) PARTICULARIZED KNOWLEDGE: Parker’s challenged statements largely post-date Sloan’s resignation. The Complaint asserts Parker had access and was copied on certain communications, but it pleads fewer concrete, contemporaneous facts showing Parker’s actual knowledge that specific public statements were false when made (as opposed to generalized awareness of ongoing regulatory work).

2) STRONG INFERENCE: Absent particularized allegations tying Parker to specific rejection letters or meetings contemporaneously contradicting his statements, innocent explanations (optimistic framing of remediation efforts; internal implementation steps continuing despite lack of formal Stage 1 approval) are at least as plausible as intent to deceive. Scienter is not pleaded with the required strength as to Parker.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) Control Person Liability (Against Insider Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
Section 20(a) is derivative. Because a primary violation under Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 is adequately pleaded and sustained as to Wells Fargo, Sloan, and Duke, the Section 20(a) claim may proceed only insofar as it is predicated on that surviving primary violation and alleges control by the relevant insider(s). The Complaint pleads Duke’s and Sloan’s control positions (CEO/President/Director; Board Chair/Regulator point of contact; involvement in disclosures), sufficient at the pleading stage.

To the extent Count II is asserted against insiders for whom the primary Section 10(b) claim is dismissed (e.g., Shrewsberry and Parker), it is dismissed because there is no adequately pleaded underlying violation as to them on this motion.

response.summary:
Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint adequately pleads actionable misstatements/omissions regarding (i) whether PINNACLE was enrolling patients (“patients are being randomized”) and (ii) whether Spectrum was “aligned” with FDA on the confirmatory trial dose/design. The complaint alleges with sufficient particularity that, at the time the statements were made, defendants Riga and Lebel had been repeatedly told by FDA in specific meetings (identified by type and date) that FDA had not agreed to the 8 mg BID confirmatory design and that PINNACLE enrollment was delayed and remained at zero. Those allegations, coupled with the later FDA briefing document/ODAC statements corroborating the substance of the prior FDA communications, support a strong inference of at least recklessness as to falsity when making present-tense statements about enrollment and FDA alignment. As to Brennan, the complaint’s scienter allegations are comparatively weaker, but she signed the Q2 10-Q repeating the “patients are being randomized” language and is alleged to have been present on the August 11 call; at the pleading stage, the complaint sufficiently ties her to the specific misstatement in the August 11 press release/10-Q and to the contemporaneous fact of zero enrollment.

Accordingly, Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is sustained. Because the underlying Exchange Act claim survives, Count II (Section 20(a)) is also sustained at this stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 (against Spectrum, Riga, Lebel, Brennan)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: Yes, as to the core alleged misstatements about (a) PINNACLE enrollment and (b) FDA “alignment.” The complaint pleads specific FDA interactions and dates (e.g., Dec. 13, 2021 pre–Phase 3 meeting; Feb. 7, 2022 End of Phase 2 meeting; May 18, 2022 midcycle; July 28, 2022 Type B; Sept. 8, 2022 late cycle) in which FDA allegedly told Riga and/or Lebel that dose-optimization data were inadequate, that FDA had not reached agreement on the 8 mg BID confirmatory design and that moving forward would be “at [Spectrum’s] risk,” and that enrollment was delayed and remained at zero. Those allegations are not merely “knew or should have known” assertions; they identify the who (Riga/Lebel), what (FDA non-agreement; inadequate data; no enrollment), when (specific meeting dates), and how (FDA communications during formal FDA meeting types). The complaint further alleges that, notwithstanding those communications, Riga and Lebel made present-tense, concrete statements on March 17, May 12, and August 11, 2022 that Spectrum had “learned to optimize” dosing, that “patients are being randomized,” and that Spectrum was “obviously aligned with FDA” on the confirmatory study. The allegation that, in fact, no patients had enrolled as of those dates directly contradicts the present-tense enrollment statements and supports knowledge/recklessness.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: The pleaded facts support a strong inference of at least recklessness for Riga and Lebel. It is more cogent than any innocent explanation that executives repeatedly warned by FDA about lack of agreement and zero enrollment nevertheless described the trial as enrolling (“patients are being randomized”) and represented FDA alignment. An innocent explanation (e.g., imprecise phrasing, misunderstanding of “initiated” vs. “enrolling,” or belief that alignment existed informally) is less plausible given the alleged repeated FDA warnings that there was no formal agreement and that proceeding was at Spectrum’s risk, and given the binary nature of the enrollment fact (zero patients). The ODAC/FDA briefing materials are alleged to corroborate that FDA had been communicating these concerns throughout development and review, which strengthens the inference that defendants’ contrary public statements were at least reckless.

As to Brennan, scienter is a closer question because the complaint attributes most FDA-meeting communications to Riga/Lebel. But Brennan is alleged to have signed the Q2 10-Q and participated in the August 11 call while the August 11 press release again stated “patients are being randomized,” and the complaint alleges the true contemporaneous fact was zero enrollment. At the pleading stage, that suffices to plead at least recklessness as to repeating a concrete, verifiable enrollment status in a public filing/press release, though Brennan’s scienter allegations are notably thinner than Riga/Lebel’s.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Riga, Lebel, Brennan)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because the complaint adequately pleads a primary violation under Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 at this stage, the Section 20(a) claim is not dismissed on that ground. The complaint also pleads control through executive roles and alleged authority over public statements and SEC filings. (If Count I had been dismissed for failure to plead scienter, Count II would also be dismissed.)

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards and focusing on scienter, the Complaint adequately pleads a strong inference that Capone knowingly made false statements about (1) his own educational credentials and (2) the Medicaid sign-ups/UnitedHealthcare relationship, because those are facts uniquely within his personal knowledge and the Complaint pleads later admissions/contradictions directly tied to those statements. As to the CBP contract valuation and “credibility to win” assertions, the Complaint pleads falsity largely through later-reported third-party sources and does not plead particularized contemporaneous facts showing Capone (or any other Individual Defendant) actually knew the contract value was lower when he spoke; innocent explanations (mistake, misunderstanding, reliance on others, or imprecision about ceiling vs. expected award) are at least as plausible on the current allegations. As to Vashovsky and Oberholzer, the Complaint largely relies on position, access, and generalized assertions of oversight rather than particularized facts showing their actual knowledge of falsity at the time of the challenged statements. Accordingly, Count I is sustained only as to Capone and only as to the credential and Medicaid/UHC misstatements; it is dismissed as to DocGo, Vashovsky, and Oberholzer for failure to plead scienter with particularity. Because §20(a) is derivative, Count II is dismissed in full as pleaded (it is asserted against “all defendants,” including the issuer, and is not tethered to a properly pleaded primary violation by a controlled person).

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (Against All Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge-of-falsity allegations: As to Capone, yes in part. The Complaint pleads Capone repeatedly represented he held a graduate degree in computational learning theory / an M.S. from Clarkson and tied that credential to DocGo’s AI “backbone.” It further pleads a later public admission that he did not have any master’s degree and that Clarkson had no record of his enrollment. Those allegations support that Capone knew the credential statements were false when made because the truth of his own education is uniquely within his personal knowledge. Likewise, the Complaint pleads Capone stated DocGo had already signed up “over 3,000” asylum seekers for NY Medicaid through UnitedHealthcare and had the ability to enroll them in United’s managed care program, and later reporting quotes both a DocGo spokesperson that DocGo does not enroll anyone in Medicaid and a UnitedHealthcare representative that DocGo had no NY contract—supporting an inference Capone knew (or was reckless in not knowing) these operational facts when he made the statements.

As to the CBP contract value (“over $4 billion”), the Complaint pleads falsity primarily through a later news article citing a CBP spokeswoman and unnamed sources stating the contract was under $2 billion. It does not plead particularized contemporaneous facts showing what Capone actually knew at the time (e.g., specific bid documents, internal emails, board materials, pricing schedules, or witness accounts showing he was told the value was below $2B). On these allegations, knowledge is not pleaded with the required particularity.

As to DocGo, Vashovsky, and Oberholzer, the Complaint relies largely on their roles, “oversight,” access to information, and their signatures/participation in SEC filings, without particularized facts showing they actually knew Capone’s credentials were false (e.g., specific diligence steps they took/failed to take, specific documents contradicting the credentials that were presented to them, or particular meetings where the falsity was discussed). PSLRA does not permit scienter to be inferred from corporate position alone.

2) Strong inference vs. innocent explanations: For Capone’s credential statements, the inference of knowing falsity is cogent and compelling because an executive’s own degrees are not plausibly a matter of confusion over time; the more plausible inference is intentional misrepresentation. For the Medicaid/UHC statements, the inference of scienter is also strong because the statements were concrete (quantified sign-ups and a specific payer relationship) and later contradicted by statements attributed to the company and the payer; on the pleadings, it is at least as plausible Capone knowingly overstated or fabricated these facts to reassure investors amid HPD scrutiny.

By contrast, for the CBP contract valuation statements, innocent explanations (misunderstanding the total ceiling vs. expected award, reliance on preliminary/contested figures, or imprecision in describing a large multi-year solicitation) are at least as plausible as fraudulent intent given the absence of particularized contemporaneous facts showing Capone knew the true value when he spoke.

Disposition: The claim is sustained only to the extent it is based on Capone’s alleged misstatements about his educational credentials and the Medicaid/UHC sign-up assertions. It is dismissed as to (a) the CBP contract valuation/‘credibility to win’ theory for failure to plead scienter with particularity, and (b) DocGo, Vashovsky, and Oberholzer for failure to plead particularized facts supporting a strong inference of scienter as to those defendants.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (Against All Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a properly pleaded underlying §10(b) violation by a controlled person and plausible control by the §20(a) defendant. The Complaint asserts §20(a) against “all defendants,” including DocGo itself, and does not plead a coherent control-person theory limited to proper control defendants tied to a sustained primary violation. Moreover, because the Court dismisses Count I as to DocGo, Vashovsky, and Oberholzer, there is no adequately pleaded primary violation supporting §20(a) liability against them. While Count I is sustained in part as to Capone, the §20(a) count as pleaded is not properly tethered to that limited surviving primary theory and is therefore dismissed.

response.summary:
Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Exchange Act claims (Counts I and II) adequately plead particularized facts supporting a strong inference that at least certain individual defendants (most notably CEO Shashua, and plausibly CFO Heller) knew, when key statements were made, that Mobileye’s reported EyeQ “demand,” “market conditions” narrative, and “inventory stabilization” assurances were misleading because shipments were being driven by enforced annual minimum commitments and end-of-year “push” deliveries that created (and concealed) a multi-year channel inventory build. The complaint relies on two confidential witnesses with asserted first-hand roles (one at Aptiv; one a Mobileye VP reporting up through a chain to Shashua) and ties those accounts to specific public statements and later admissions (Jan. 2024) that the annual commitments made it “impossible” for customers to adjust quantities. Those allegations, taken collectively, support a cogent and compelling inference of scienter that is at least as strong as innocent explanations (e.g., mere forecasting error or surprise). Because the underlying Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claims are sustained, the derivative Exchange Act Section 20(a) control-person claim (Count III) is also sustained at the pleading stage.

The Securities Act claims (Counts IV and V) are not subject to PSLRA scienter pleading. The complaint plausibly alleges actionable misstatements/omissions in the Offering Documents about the nature and prevalence of minimum-quantity commitments and about demand/inventory trends, including Item 303/105 omissions, sufficient to proceed under Sections 11 and 15.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(b) (misstatements/omissions) against Mobileye and Executive Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: The complaint pleads more than conclusory “knew or should have known” allegations. It alleges (a) a Mobileye senior former employee (FE2), VP of ADAS Business Development (through end of 2022), who states the excess-inventory push existed “across the board,” was already “significant” by end-2022, and that the decision to push inventory “went up to Amnon” (CEO Shashua). FE2 also alleges that executive management including the CFO (Heller) attended quarterly meetings where out-of-ordinary Tier 1 issues and reports were discussed. (b) a former Aptiv employee (FE1) describing annual minimum-commitment operation, inability to cancel, and Mobileye’s year-end delivery of remaining quantities “without question,” despite Aptiv’s reduced OEM demand. These accounts are tied to specific challenged statements during 2023 (e.g., volumes “depend upon market conditions,” inventory “stabilized,” no requests to push volumes, and representations minimizing commitments as “generally” absent) and to later admissions (Jan. 2024) that full-year commitments made it “impossible” for customers to adjust quantities. These allegations, if true, support actual contemporaneous knowledge that at least some statements about demand tracking, inventory stabilization, and shipment dependence on market conditions were misleading.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: Considering the allegations holistically, the inference that defendants intentionally (or with deliberate recklessness) misled investors about the demand/inventory dynamics is cogent and at least as compelling as an innocent inference of mere misforecasting. The alleged scheme is multi-year, involves core revenue driver (EyeQ ~90% of revenue), and includes alleged internal escalation to the CEO and customer objections. The complaint also pleads later admissions that the annual commitments constrained customers’ ability to adjust, undermining an innocent “we didn’t know” narrative. While defendants may ultimately argue benign explanations (e.g., customers voluntarily built inventory; management misread the data; macro volatility), at the pleading stage the witness accounts plus admissions and the described mechanics of forced year-end deliveries support a strong inference of scienter.

Individual-defendant nuance: The strongest scienter allegations are as to Shashua (FE2: decision ‘went up to Amnon’). Scienter is also plausibly pleaded as to Heller based on alleged quarterly executive meetings addressing unusual Tier 1 issues and the centrality of EyeQ revenue. Scienter allegations are weaker as to later CFO Rojansky (joined mid-2023) and communications officer Galves, but the complaint attributes multiple specific statements to them and pleads an overarching course of conduct; at this stage, the Court cannot parse liability with sufficient precision to dismiss them from Count I on scienter grounds alone given the collective factual narrative and their alleged involvement in making/approving the challenged statements.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(a) and (c) (scheme liability) against Mobileye and Executive Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity/illegality: The alleged scheme is not pleaded as mere “fraud by hindsight.” Plaintiffs plead specific operational conduct—imposing annual minimum commitments, refusing cancellations, shipping remaining committed quantities at year-end without purchase orders, and recognizing revenue—supported by FE1 and FE2. FE2 further alleges escalation to CEO Shashua. Those allegations support knowledge of the underlying conduct forming the purported deceptive scheme.

2) Strong inference of scienter: The same facts supporting Count I support a strong inference of scienter for scheme liability. The alleged conduct (forcing excess product into the channel, then publicly attributing results to demand/market conditions and assuring inventory was stable) is plausibly deceptive rather than merely aggressive sales strategy, particularly given allegations of customer objections and the later admission that the commitment structure made demand adjustment “impossible.” Innocent explanations (ordinary supply-chain contracting, forecasting error, or customers’ unilateral inventory decisions) are less compelling at this stage because the complaint pleads that customers sought to cancel and Mobileye would not allow it, and that Mobileye could ‘push’ product into customers (including Magna CFO’s later statement that Mobileye could do what Magna could not).

claim_rulings.claim: Count III — Section 20(a) (control person liability) against Executive Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because Counts I and II (primary violations) are sustained, the Section 20(a) claim is not dismissed on that basis. The complaint also pleads control through executive positions and alleged involvement in making/approving the challenged statements. Scienter is not an independent PSLRA element for Section 20(a) in the same manner as Section 10(b), though defendants may later contest control and culpable participation.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IV — Section 11 (Securities Act) against Mobileye, Shashua, and Heller
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not required for Section 11. Plaintiffs plausibly allege material misstatements/omissions in the Offering Documents (incorporating the 2022 Form 10-K and Q1 2023 10-Q), including statements that Mobileye ‘generally’ lacked minimum-quantity contracts and that volumes supplied would ‘depend upon market conditions,’ while allegedly the dominant Tier 1 customers were subject to annual minimum commitments that made it ‘impossible’ to adjust quantities and had already produced 4–5 million excess EyeQ units by the time of the June 2023 offering. Plaintiffs also plausibly plead Item 303/105 omissions regarding known trends/uncertainties and risk factors tied to excess channel inventory and revenue pull-forward. These allegations suffice at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Count V — Section 15 (Securities Act) against Shashua and Heller
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 15 is derivative of a viable Section 11 claim. Because Count IV is sustained, Count V is also sustained at the pleading stage. Plaintiffs plausibly plead control based on Shashua’s and Heller’s roles and their signing of the Registration Statement.

response.summary: Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed under the PSLRA because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that any defendant knew the challenged statements were false when made (or acted with deliberate recklessness). The allegations rely heavily on generalized “must have known” theories, confidential-witness impressions not tied to what each Individual Defendant actually received or reviewed at the time, and post-class “admissions” that are at least as consistent with non-fraudulent misjudgment and later course-correction as with an intent to deceive. Because the Section 10(b) claim is dismissed, Count II (Section 20(a)) is also dismissed as derivative.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Exchange Act §10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against American, Isom, May, Raja)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: The complaint pleads that internal tools (SalesLink/PRISM/IATA) showed NDC adoption lagging and corporate/agency share declining, and that CWs observed booking declines (e.g., 15% YoY decline at large agencies; corporate accounts “much lower”). But it does not plead with the required particularity that any Individual Defendant actually received, reviewed, or was presented those specific adverse metrics at the time of the challenged statements. The CW allegations describe CW1/CW2’s access and observations and, at most, assert in generalized fashion that “Defendants knew” because such data existed or was “available,” which is insufficient under the PSLRA. There are no dates, recipients, meeting materials, dashboards, emails, or report distributions alleged tying (i) specific negative figures, (ii) to a specific defendant, (iii) before or contemporaneous with the particular statements (July 2023 through April 2024). The complaint also relies on the defendants’ senior roles and the importance of distribution strategy (a “core operations” theory) to infer knowledge; that is not a substitute for particularized facts of actual knowledge.

The risk-factor theory (that risks were framed as hypothetical though “actualized”) likewise does not supply scienter. Even if the complaint plausibly pleads that the distribution initiative was causing headwinds, it does not plead that defendants knew, at the time of each filing, that the described risks had already materialized to a degree that made the statements misleading, as opposed to being within the range of expected transition volatility.

The Bain/Bloomberg allegations do not cure the defect. The complaint pleads that Bain performed a “critical review” and that Raja was fired after feedback. But it does not plead when Bain was retained, what Bain reported, when each Individual Defendant received the report, or what specific findings were known before the April 25, 2024 statements. Those allegations remain speculative as to timing and content.

Post-class statements (May 29 and July 25, 2024) describing execution missteps and revenue impacts do not, without more, plead contemporaneous knowledge of falsity. They are consistent with later-learned information, evolving market conditions, or management’s reassessment and corrective action. Using later disclosures to infer earlier fraud risks “fraud by hindsight.”

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that American pursued an aggressive strategic transition (Modern Retailing/NDC), encountered stronger-than-expected resistance and operational/servicing frictions, and initially believed—perhaps overly optimistically—that adoption would accelerate and that revenue softness would reverse. The complaint itself quotes Isom’s later statement that management “thought that was going to reverse itself. It didn’t,” which supports non-fraudulent misjudgment rather than an intent to deceive. The challenged statements are largely optimistic assessments (e.g., being “encouraged,” “pleased,” “comfortable,” “on track,” “nothing that I see”), mixed with forward-looking guidance. Even assuming some statements could be actionable if knowingly false, the complaint does not plead particularized contemporaneous facts making it cogent and at least as compelling that defendants knew the opposite (e.g., that corporate revenues were not “coming back very materially” as of April 25, 2024).

Because the complaint does not plead scienter with the PSLRA-required particularity as to any defendant, the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Exchange Act §20(a) (control person liability against Isom, May, Raja)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation of the Exchange Act. Because Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, Count II is also dismissed.
